messages.message: I do not, check with the project lead :slightly_smiling_face:

Whatever the project was, the people on that team would be the people to ask. In this case, if it was deleted you wouldn’t be able to find it retroactively, but the people you worked with should be able to point you in the right direction.
oops i asked @Jesika Haria to do that (so that it doesn’t conflict with the `AppsTeam` jira project) — both of us thought it wasn’t used at all

A few super handy Jira filters that I use almost daily are:
• Created recently https://instabase.atlassian.net/issues/?filter=10129
• Updated recently https://instabase.atlassian.net/issues/?filter=-8
Yes, so the APPS-112 issue was for the Diff app doc work https://github.com/instabase/instabase-docs/pull/111

it contained the conversation, the work details, and the assets

I'll need to request those assets again, and try to remember the other work.
So... I can do this (grumble grumble).

Situations like this are another reason we all need to be good Jira citizens, keep the issues up to date, and the status current. (APPS-112 was current)
Not sure if this is anti-jira practice, but given the way we have been operating, i’d recommend having a dedicated project for docs/training materials.

We do, it's the IBG project. Having a dedicated project is not anti-Jira practice for general docs work. However, (there is a _however_ here) I've seen success in organizations that use the engineering Jira projects to also have issues for the related technical content work, since this technical content development and maintenance requires engineering effort and needs to be planned and scoped as part of the release process.
For example, FLOW-110 covers the content for UDFs in Flow.
got it — then part of the problem there is that diff doesn’t exactly have an owner atm. once there is an ownership team, that team’s project would be the one to use.
(or maybe diff does have an owner now — it didn’t as of the eng reorg a few weeks ago)
The challenges of rapid growth and shifts. I get it. Another reason to be good Jira citizens, know who's on first.
I think one of the things we can do going forward is make sure to talk it out in <#CLHT3AXGV|> before deleting projects so we can make sure everyone is on the same page.

Yeah, that’s a good idea. Another method is if we are going to delete a project, simply treat it like a deprecation in software - leave an comment on any open issues saying the project is being deprecated for x,y,z and give a date to migrate stuff to a different project.
I think we can even go so far as to say if there are open tasks, we shouldn’t delete it without moving or closing those tasks.
